page.title: 01STRADBROKE AND DISTRICT
page.content: The landscape is flat to gently undulating, chiefly given over to arable crops such as cereals, sugar beet and oilseed rape. Very little grassland, but two dairy herds and some intensive pig and poultry husbandry. Very sparse woodland of ash, elm etc. The soil is boulder clay. The population is roughly 1100, mostly occupied with the needs of the farming community and some light industry. Stradbroke was formerly a market town with its own railway station, now vanished. Public transport being minimal, most people rely on their own car for reaching their place of work and for such shopping items as cannot be obtained within the village. The Primary and High Schools serve surrounding villages, and pupils transfer to Framlingham, for VIth Form education.
